macros.vba_code:
Option Explicit

#If Win32 Or Win64 Then
    Private Type Os
        Arch As Boolean
    End Type
#Else
    Private Type Os
        Arch As String
    End Type
#End If

#If Win64 Or Win32 Then
    #If VBA7 Then
            Private Type PI
                hP        As LongPtr
                hT         As LongPtr
                dPI     As Long
                dTI      As Long
            End Type
        
            Private Type SI
                cb              As Long
                lR      As LongPtr
                lD       As LongPtr
                lT         As LongPtr
                dX             As Long
                dY             As Long
                dXS         As Long
                dYS         As Long
                dXCC   As Long
                dYCC   As Long
                dFA As Long
                dF         As Long
                wSW     As Integer
                cR2     As Integer
                lR2     As Byte
                hSI       As LongPtr
macros.properties: auto-close auto-open environ powershell run-dll run-file

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of a Windows system binary that is usually located in the system folder from an uncommon location.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Patrick Bareiss, Anton Kutepov, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=\??\C:\Windows\system32\conhost.exe; Image=\??\C:\Windows\system32\conhost.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: File With Uncommon Extension Created By An Office Application
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of files with an executable or script extension by an Office application.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Vadim Khrykov (ThreatIntel), Cyb3rEng (Rule), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{RuleName=DLL; Image=C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; TargetFilename=C:\ProgramData\cscui.dll; EventID=11}
@{Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; TargetFilename=C:\ProgramData\cscui.dll; EventID=11}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=2F34CCFDD8141AEEE2E89FFB070CE239C7D00706,MD5=73C519F050C20580F8A62C849D49215A,SHA256=38847DC4C82C0775E7DAFCBC7FEA50749CDAC7B50AB8602E8FDFAD4401954C87,IMPHASH=F27A7FC3A53E74F45BE370131953896A; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\george\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=RUNDLL32.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows host process (Rundll32); FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; CommandLine=C:\Windows/system32/rundll32.exe "C:\ProgramData/cscui.dll", #1; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious start of rundll32.exe without any parameters as found in CobaltStrike beacon activity

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential System DLL Sideloading From Non System Locations
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects DLL sideloading of DLLs usually located in system locations (System32, SysWOW64, etc.).

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Hashes=SHA1=CC725E9D1F9ABBC7BAD0A29420C07EE95DDFABF2,MD5=DB5F4EE7652A24663E84F3F4A50F2B05,SHA256=64D36DBB92937377E8174249BEB4DF1A5449D8C656C026C26CA3B5DD4FADE2F5,IMPHASH=A13A1435C89F61DC1C0DD6B9A3E80707; OriginalFileName=cscui.dll; ImageLoaded=C:\ProgramData\cscui.dll; Description=User CSA Library; SignatureStatus=Unavailable; EventID=7; FileVersion=6.1.7600.16385; Signed=false; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Company}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Unsigned DLL Loaded by Windows Utility
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects windows utilities loading an unsigned or untrusted DLL.
Adversaries often abuse those programs to proxy execution of malicious code.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Hashes=SHA1=CC725E9D1F9ABBC7BAD0A29420C07EE95DDFABF2,MD5=DB5F4EE7652A24663E84F3F4A50F2B05,SHA256=64D36DBB92937377E8174249BEB4DF1A5449D8C656C026C26CA3B5DD4FADE2F5,IMPHASH=A13A1435C89F61DC1C0DD6B9A3E80707; SignatureStatus=Unavailable; ImageLoaded=C:\ProgramData\cscui.dll; Description=User CSA Library; OriginalFileName=cscui.dll; FileVersion=6.1.7600.16385; EventID=7; Signed=false; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Company=Microsoft Company}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=true; DestinationPort=53; DestinationIp=808:808:6375:7269:7479:4465:7363:7269; Protocol=udp; SourceIp=c0a8:21a:7080:500:9820:c7e:88e4:ffff; DestinationIsIpv6=true; EventID=3; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; SourcePort=56183; Initiated=true}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Rundll32 Execution With Uncommon DLL Extension
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of rundll32 with a command line that doesn't contain a common extension
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Tim Shelton, Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Yassine Oukessou

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; Image=C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

match_context.values: @{TargetFilename=C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\~$Normal.dotm}
@{TargetFilename=C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\Normal.dotm}
@{TargetFilename=C:\Users\Administrator\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\~$Normal.dotm}

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 10.0, Code page: 1252, Author: User, Template: Normal.dotm, Last Saved By: User, Revision Number: 11, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Office Word, Total Editing Time: 14:00, Create Time/Date: Tue Feb 13 07:15:00 2024, Last Saved Time/Date: Tue Feb 13 07:30:00 2024, Number of Pages: 4, Number of Words: 351, Number of Characters: 2001, Security: 0

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macro code starts by defining several types and declaring Windows API functions, primarily related to file and process manipulation.  These include `CreateProcessW` (aliased as `CreateImage`), `ReadFile` (aliased as `ReadImage`), `GetFileSize` (aliased as `GetImageSize`), `WriteFile` (aliased as `WriteImage`), `CloseHandle` (aliased as `CloseImage`), `Sleep` (aliased as `WaitForImage`), and `CreateFileW` (aliased as `DeleteImage`).  It also uses `GetFileAttributesW` (aliased as `GetImageResolution`).

The `Document_Open` subroutine initializes several variables, including a key (`key`), the document path (`pdw`), paths to a DLL (`dPaw`) and a PNG file (`dEaw`), and constructs a command string (`pAaw`).  It attempts to retrieve values from document variables named "Text1" and "Text2", storing them in `kw` and `ky` respectively. It then calls the `testImage` subroutine and the `MacrosEnabled` subroutine.

The `testImage` subroutine sets the document view to print view, unprotects the document if it's protected, and checks if a file exists at a specific path (`imagesFolder`).  It searches for a shape with the alternative text "hnmet hide". If the shape is found and the file check returns a specific value, the `lock_document` subroutine is called with the shape as an argument.  The document is then protected again.

The `MacrosEnabled` subroutine unprotects the document, changes the font color to black, deletes a bookmark if it exists, calls the `process_document` subroutine, and then reprotects the document.

The `process_document` and `close_document` subroutines iterate through the document's shapes, setting their visibility based on their alternative text (either hiding or showing shapes based on whether their alternative text contains "hide" or "show").

The `lock_document` subroutine constructs a command string that appears to add a registry key using `reg.exe`. The key path suggests manipulation of InProcServer32 registry entry related to COM objects. It retrieves data from the alternative text of the shape passed to it (splitting the text by "||"). It then calls the `unlock_document` subroutine with the constructed command. The `lock_document` subroutine reads the size of a file specified by `dPaw`. If the file does not exist, it processes embedded data from a shape with the alternative text containing "hnmet hide". This embedded data is extracted, and the `Unblur` function is called with `dPaw` and `dEaw`, and extracted data and sizes.  Finally, it creates and executes a process using `rundll32.exe` with `pAaw` (seemingly, to execute the previously dropped DLL).

The `unlock_document` subroutine creates a process using `CreateProcessW` and seems to be called with commands for reg.exe.

The `SearchShape` function searches for a shape (inline or regular) by its alternative text and returns it.

The `Document_Close` subroutine unprotects the document, calls `close_document`, reprotects the document, and then saves the document.

The `get_img_bytes`, `search_image_start_end`, `getPixel`, `Gaussian`, `Blur`, and `Unblur` functions appear to handle byte array manipulation and file I/O.  These functions seem to retrieve bytes from Enhanced MetaFile in shapes in the document. The bytes are processed, and some are written to files (with names obtained from environment variables and document variables), including a DLL (`dPaw`) and potentially a PNG file (`dEaw`). The registry manipulation suggests persistence.  The use of `rundll32.exe` to execute a DLL, along with the complex byte manipulation, strongly suggests malicious behavior.

The provided macros exhibit several behaviors commonly associated with malicious intent. Here are the key points of analysis:

1. Obfuscation Techniques: The code contains numerous obfuscated strings and variable names, which is a common tactic used by malware authors to hide their true intentions. For example, the use of concatenated strings to form paths and commands (e.g., `dPaw`, `dEaw`) makes it difficult to understand the actual operations being performed at first glance.

2. Suspicious Function Calls: The macros make extensive use of Windows API calls such as `CreateProcessW`, `ReadFile`, `WriteFile`, and `GetFileSize`. These functions can be leveraged to execute external programs, read from files, and write data, which raises red flags regarding potential file manipulation or execution of unauthorized binaries.

3. Persistence Mechanisms: The macro attempts to manipulate the Windows registry using commands that add entries under `HKCU\Software`. This behavior indicates an attempt to establish persistence on the system, allowing the malware to run automatically upon system startup.

4. Document Protection and Manipulation: The macros include functionality to protect the document with a password (`ThisDocument.Protect wdAllowOnlyFormFields, Password:=kw`). This could prevent users from easily accessing or modifying the document, thereby hiding malicious activities.

5. Execution of External Files: The presence of code that constructs a command to execute a potentially harmful executable (`undll32.exe`) suggests that the macro is designed to download, write, and execute files without user consent. This is a clear indicator of malicious behavior.

6. Self-Replication and Propagation: The use of the `Auto_Open()` subroutine implies that the macros will execute automatically when the document is opened, which is a typical characteristic of macro viruses.

7. Manipulation of Security Settings: The macros also check for and modify the protection status of the document, indicating an effort to bypass security measures that would alert the user to suspicious activity.

8. Error Handling: The use of `On Error Resume Next` throughout the code allows the macros to continue executing even if errors occur, which can be a method to avoid detection and maintain control over the execution flow.

Overall, the combination of these factors strongly indicates that the macros are designed with malicious intent, aiming to compromise the host system's integrity and security.
